instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL is another way to say SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL, look at the definition provided for SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL as it applies to .
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-2838: What is 820-2838? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2327: What is 820-2327? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
threads.message:
Hi guys ,
need help on this board . it is running fine on the charger but does not detect battery , i have checked the resisitor <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> , the both are showing 2.0k
there is no short to gnd on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA</SIGNAL>. i have already changed the isl but no change . the strange thing which i have noticed is
the <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> getting extremely hot . i replaced that aswell but no luck . 
 ( it has a cross on battery icon hence not detecting the battery ) 
plz advise thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
threads.message: Try with another known good battery.... If remove battery, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> still getting hot???? What voltage do you have on SMBUS lines??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
threads.message:
hi ,
thanks for the reply , <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> is getting hot without the battery . i will check the  voltages and update thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
threads.message:
How did this come to be? Someone replacing the battery and shorting pins? Water? Out of nowhere?

There are four items in this circuit. The battery, the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, the SMC, and the battery indicator/sleep sensor/LED thingie on the side.

You replaced the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Unplug the sleep sensor/battery indicator thingie. Does it see the battery?

If not, try good battery.

Does it still not see a battery?

If it doesn't, at this point, it is the SMC.

But give some better history.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
threads.message:
hi Aprendiz and Louis , 
                                                  Thanks for the update and information , it came from another repair shop ,  i am attaching some pics , please have a look , i think on  <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>   the voltage should drop to 12.6 v  but it does not drop and stays between 17 to 18  volts on pin 1,2,3 and also gate voltage at pin 4 . it gets hot without the battery . No shorts to ground on battery pins apart from the 3 ground pins which i suppose are meant to be that way . on the smc line resistors the voltages are 3.4 volts and on f7040 the voltage is between 17-18 volts which i suppose should be less . 

please look at the attached pics ,  I found these solder blobs but they are not shorting anywhere until there is a track here which goes to smc but i doubt that .  Machine is not even slow . this one is proving to be difficult and beyond logic .
 i have cleaned the solder blobs and replaced the <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> ,  changed the caps around <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> . No idea but do not want to give up .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> getting hot can only really be caused by a dead 6259, bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> or 7035 or the traces to the gates of them. Battery detection will probably be 6259 or SMC.
If you remove the 6259 it should still work on the battery if it is recognized.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
threads.message:
thanks for the response ,
          <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> kept on getting hot  , this time rather than replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> first i replaced the isl and then replaced the <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> , now it is not getting hot but now on battery plugged in i was getting   very low output from <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>) and  after replacing <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> i have 3.42 volts but the board does not start ( battery not recognized)  .  As there is no short on smc data lines i think smc itself is faulty but  finding a working smc from another board and replacing it is a torture .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
threads.message: it is, and you're going to go do it anyway for practice and report back how it went. :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
threads.message:
hi,       
           that board went away but i am replacing the smc on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a, i have removed it successfully but now i am unsure that either an smc taken from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2327</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> will work on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  i or will  not work  ?
logically the new smc's can be programmed differently so no idea. Also i need to replace smc on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> but do no have the same board as donor . so kindly advise as which smc's are compatible . thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - not detecting battery
threads.message: Get the exact SMC from a donor board, do not try to swap them around too much wasted time.
